Introduction

The major histocompatibility complex (MHC) (known as human leukocyte antigen [HLA] in humans) plays a central role in adaptive immunity by allowing antigenic peptides to be presented to T lymphocytes.  MHC molecules provide a molecular signature of "self" and are essential for immune surveillance and tolerance.  Located on chromosome 6, the corresponding genomic region is one of the most genetically diverse regions and influences susceptibility to infection, autoimmune disease, and transplant outcomes.  MHC molecules are broadly categorized into class I and class II, each with distinct cellular distributions, structures, and functions.

Molecular structure and function

MHC class I



MHC class I molecules (

figure 1
) are expressed on the surface of all nucleated cells and consist of a heavy alpha chain paired with beta-2-microglobulin.  The MHC class I pathway typically processes proteins that are found in the cytoplasm, including damaged cellular and viral proteins.  This pathway is especially important for facilitating the identification and destruction of virally infected cells by CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes.  Peptide processing first involves degradation by proteasomes.  The peptides are then removed from the cytosol by transporters associated with antigen processing (TAP) proteins, which stud the membrane of the endoplasmic reticulum.  Once inside the endoplasmic reticulum, the peptides assemble with transmembrane polypeptide and beta-2-microglobulin to form MHC class I molecules that traverse the Golgi apparatus to insert into the plasma membrane:



  • Encoded by:  HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C.
  • Recognized by:  CD8+ T cells.
  • Antigen origin:  Cytosolic (eg, viral proteins, tumor antigens).

MHC class II



MHC class II molecules (

figure 2
) are expressed primarily on antigen-presenting cells (APCs), including dendritic cells, macrophages, and B cells.  They recognize extracellular proteins, which are engulfed and degraded into peptide fragments in phagolysosomes.  Each MHC II molecule consists of an alpha and a beta chain; the invariant chain brings these chains together to form a stable complex in the endoplasmic reticulum.  The MHC-invariant complex then passes through the Golgi apparatus and enters an endosome in which the invariant chain is proteolytically degraded; the endosome merges with the phagolysosome containing the extracellular peptide, which is inserted between the alpha and the beta chains.  This newly formed MHC class IIâ€“peptide complex travels to the APC surface, where it is expressed and recognized by CD4+ T-helper cells.



  • Encoded by:  HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR (2 letters, like MHC II).
  • Recognized by:  CD4+ T cells.
  • Antigen origin:  Endosomal/phagolysosomal (eg, bacterial proteins, extracellular viral particles).

HLA genetics and inheritance



The HLA region comprises thousands of alleles that differ at key amino acid residues involved in peptide binding.  This polymorphism allows for broad antigenic coverage at the population level but introduces challenges in transplantation and disease association studies.



Each individual inherits one HLA haplotype from each parent.  Because of the compact nature of the HLA locus on chromosome 6, recombination is rare, and the haplotypes are often inherited intact.  Therefore, siblings generally have:



  • 25% chance for a full HLA match.
  • 50% chance of sharing one haplotype (haploidentical).
  • 25% chance of sharing no haplotype.


This pattern is foundational in donor selection for hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

Clinical implications

Transplantation



HLA matching is essential in allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell and solid organ transplantation.  Mismatches between donor and recipient HLA alleles increase the risk for graft rejection and graft versus host disease.  The most critical loci for matching include:



  • Class I:  HLA-A, HLA-B, HLA-C
  • Class II:  HLA-DR, HLA-DQ (HLA-DP less commonly typed)


Stem cell donor sources include:



  • Autologous:  Patient's own cells; no risk for immunologic incompatibility.
  • Syngeneic:  Identical twin; perfect HLA match.
  • Allogeneic:  Related or unrelated donor with a full or partial HLA match.


Unrelated donors can still be used successfully when high-resolution molecular HLA typing ensures close matching.

Immunodeficiency



Loss or malfunction of MHC molecules results in profound immunologic consequences:



  • Bare lymphocyte syndrome type I:  Defects in TAP genes lead to deficient MHC class I expression, resulting in susceptibility to viral infections despite normal lymphocyte counts.
  • Bare lymphocyte syndrome type II:  Failure of MHC class II expression results in a severe combined immunodeficiency phenotype due to impaired CD4+ T-helper cell activation and antibody class switching.

Autoimmunity and disease susceptibility



Certain HLA alleles are strongly associated with autoimmune diseases and other immune-mediated conditions.  Examples include:



  • HLA-B27:  Ankylosing spondylitis, psoriatic arthritis, reactive arthritis.
  • HLA-DR3/DR4:  Type 1 diabetes mellitus.
  • HLA-DR2:  Multiple sclerosis.
  • HLA-DQ2/DQ8:  Celiac disease.
  • HLA-B*57:01:  Abacavir hypersensitivity.
  • HLA-B*15:02:  Stevens-Johnson syndrome with carbamazepine.


These associations may reflect enhanced or aberrant peptide binding by specific HLA molecules, promoting autoreactive T-cell activation.

Vaccine response



HLA allelic variability also influences immune response to vaccination.  The effectiveness of a response to T cellâ€“dependent antibody depends on the ability of an individual's MHC class II molecules to present vaccine-derived peptides.  Individuals with HLA variants that do not efficiently bind and present a given peptide may fail to generate an IgG response, although they may still mount a T cellâ€“independent IgM response.

Summary



The major histocompatibility complex (MHC)/human leukocyte antigen (HLA) genes facilitate antigen presentation and immune recognition.  MHC class I molecules present cytosolic antigens to CD8+ cytotoxic T cells, whereas MHC class II molecules present extracellular antigens to CD4+ T-helper cells.  Clinically, HLA matching plays a central role in transplantation, and specific HLA alleles confer risk for autoimmune diseases, drug hypersensitivities, and immunodeficiencies.
